H0.text: Alchemy is the practice in which practitioners believed all matter was composed of different proportions of four basic elements, and that changing these proportions could alter the substance itself.

H1.text: Chemistry is the discipline in which practitioners believed that all matter consisted of varying proportions of four basic elements, and that altering these proportions could change the substance itself.

H2.text: Biology is the field in which practitioners believed that all matter was composed of different proportions of four basic elements, and that changing the proportions of these elements could change the substance itself.

H3.text: Phrenology is the thought held by practitioners that all matter was composed of different proportions of four basic elements, and that changing the proportions of these elements could change the substance itself.

A4.text: An important example of alchemy's roots in Greek philosophy, originated by Empedocles and developed by Aristotle, was that all things in the universe were formed from only four elements: earth, air, water, and fire.
